name: Celtic revival

attributes.attribute: unlikely to wane in the near future
less resistant to the spiritual quest
root their reinvented religious practices more firmly in history

sources: Carr-Gomm, Philip. *The Druid Renaissance.* London: Thorsons, 1996.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: In the past 25 years, there has been a surge of interest in Celtic spirituality and mythology, with many individuals seeking a spiritual connection to their heritage that is relevant to modern times. The environmentally conscious are drawn to the pre-capitalistic Celtic view of land, which aligns with their post-capitalist utopian beliefs, and find the spiritual significance and fulfillment in the Celtic view of Nature. There are also those who look to Celtic literature for strong representations of women, taking a feminist or womanist perspective. Some individuals are motivated by their personal heritage and desire to connect with an imagined pagan past. Engaging with Celtic topics can take many forms, from reading books on the matter to listening to Celtic music and even embarking on self-described pilgrimages to Celtic lands, or practicing rites based on Celtic sources. Those who pursue this path may identify as pagans, Wicca, witches, Druids, or neopagans. It is worth noting that this is not a new trend; interest in Celtic lore resurfaced almost a century ago in the form of the British order of Druids, and the Celtic Twilight represented both creative and ritualistic expressions of this fascination. Despite the impressive growth of the Celtic revival, some scholars criticize its various branches for deficiencies in scholarship, such as neglecting to read original texts or seeking out reliable translations. Material deemed traditional by practitioners of Celtic revivalism has origins relatively recent, while Masonic sources, rather than Celtic, provide the base for some rituals. Furthermore, some social attitudes are without support from archaeology. Nevertheless, Celtic revivalism perseveres with little indication of decline in the nearby future. Were scholars to become more open to the spiritual quest, they would discover a receptive audience of practitioners, who in turn could reinforce the historic foundations of their reimagined religious observances.
